author: Bob (Guest)
title: Bold 9930 remove/add battery?
text: I keep getting remove/add battery with my Bold 9930 using Linux Mint Debian. Is there a special procedure, or details for doing this? Do I disconnect the USB cable first? I am looking forward to buying you something from Amazon with my BB tethered ;)

author: Faizal_Malaysia (Guest)
title: bbtether for Ubuntu 11.04
text:
Upgrade my OS from Ubuntu 10.10 to Ubuntu 11.04. Unfortunately after upgrading the OS, my bbtether unable to connect. Mesasage said that some problem with the script.
After some workaround, I notice that some minor changes need to be done on the connection profile script (I'm just using 'Zain' connect profile with my Celcom provider). Edit the Zain file (or whichever that you're using), on last line, by default it written there --> connect "/usr/sbin/chat -f conf/Zain-chat". Just put the full path of the bbtether config file like example connect "/usr/sbin/chat -f /home/<username>/bbtether/conf/Zain-chat", which the path of where you extract your bbtether package. Then try to connect again using berry4all and should be OK.

author: Yorg (Guest)
title: Working report
text: I'd like to report that I have been using Berry4All 0.3m on Linux Mint 10 with my Blackberry Bold 9700.  Only a minor problem of up\down speed slowing severely after extended use.  A restart of the application seems to fix this.

author: Kees (Guest)
title: WIndows allows 3g, Ubuntu 10.04 only 2g
text:
Hi all,

First of all, Berry4all is the only tethering program I was able to find and install that actually WORKS, so Marie Colar for president!!!!
Being new to Linux, sheesh, steep learning curve, but I managed.

Only problem I have is this known 3G/2G issue.
As said in this posts title, in my Windows XP partition using the regular BB Desktop software 6.0 I get a 3G connection and pretty good speeds with my BB Bold 9000. In my Ubuntu 10.04 partition using Bery4all, only 2G is allowed for some reason. ALthough I do see upon connecting that for a brief moment a 3G connection IS established but gets kicked out almost straight away.
The "switch 2G to 3G while connected" trick does not work as upon switching the connection between BB and the net stops for a brief moment therefor berry4all looses track also. I think that somehow Berry4all needs an extra command line somewhere in the chat script to tell the BB9000 its ok to go for 3G. ANy ideas so far?

Thx for your time,

Kees

author: Guest (Guest)
title: My 2 cents.
text: hello, I just barely found out about this program.... I was doing a research about how to install it or run it, but i couldn't find anything. It will be awesome if someone will tell me how to run it or install it. I am using a mac book pro runing snow leaopard so please help me with this thank you.

author: Tweakker (Guest)
title: Tweakker
text: get your apn settings here

author: Tweakker (Guest)
title: Tweakker gprs settings service
text: A good place to find the proper APN, user & password for your phone providers is http://www.tweakker.com. They have a free servide where you get the gprs setting in a sms message that installs automaticall on your phone.

author: Guest (Guest)
title: [Update] Rogers + 9700 = Success + Fail
text:
Update: Per comments below I tried setting 9700 to 2G mode, then established connection fine, then told BB* to use only 3G mode (the Berry4All connection stayed alive!) and thus had 3G speeds using Berry4All.

Thanks to commenters, and the original author of course.

*: Go into Options then Mobile Network and change Network Mode to be 3G (or back to 2G)

author: Jonathan Shapiro (Guest)
title: PPTP VPN on Ubuntu 9.1 using Barry
text:
Got Barry working very nicely on Ubuntu 9.1 and with a BlackBerry 8330 on Verizon Wireless.

Here's a question though.  I want to initiate a VPN connection over Barry, but the Network Manager greys out my VPN connection.  I guess it doesn't see that I'm connected over any connection it manages.  How can I get around this and launch my VPN connection?

author: Guest (Guest)
title: BOLD 9700
text:
My BOLD 9700 appears to be working now in 2G mode. The trick for me was removing the dash in the cfg file 'tmobile-epc-chat'.

Old line: OK 'AT+CGDCONT=1,"IP","epc.t-mobile.com"'
new line: OK 'AT+CGDCONT=1,"IP","epc.tmobile.com"'

I noticed this might be an issue when checking the APN setting on my phone in the advanced:TCP/IP screen which also had epc.tmobile.com without the dash.  I also used a blank username and password BTW.

3G=754/79

TIMEOUT 10

----------------------------------------

# Another one for other phones(Compressed images - good for 3G). epc.t-mobile.com
connect "/usr/sbin/chat -f conf/tmobile-epc-chat"
----------------------------------------

The Bold 9700 is 3G but I set it to "2G"-only, when I try to tether..

author: Guest (Guest)
title: 3G on T-Mobile USA
text: I upgraded my 8820 to a Bold 9700.  Using 3G I couldn't get an IP address.  I read above and switched to 2G and it worked.  While still connected I changed the phone back to 3G and remained connected.  I'm getting .6Mb/S Down and .07 Up.  It's one extra step, but I'm not complaining.  Thank you for the app!

author: bond17_007 (Guest)
title: Sprint PAM Issue
text: I started having issue with Sprint, as it gives me "No Carrier" Error. (in the help i was able to confirm that sprint has blocked PAM). But I found interesting that "Theterberry" still works fine. I was wondering if there are any plans/ way to make berry4all similar so that we put one client on our bb device and one on ubuntu rather than pure PAM, making the carrier think that request is coming from phone rather than PAM.

author: PKC (Guest)
title: US Cellular 3 of 3
text:
berry4all script and settings -- US Cellular

by P.K. Carlisle 2009-11-03

Tested and working on U.S. Cellular with a Blackberry 8330 Curve



uscc and uscc-chat notes



This was tested and working November, 2009 with



- a US Cellular Blackberry Curve 8330 OS version 4.5.0.138

- OpenSUSE 11.1

- kernel 2.6.27.90-135 default

- Gnome 2.24.1

- Python 2.6.0-2.21.1

- ppp 0.3.23-5.2

- barry-gui 0.14-24.1

- barry-util 0.14-24.1

- libbarry0 0.14-23.1

- barry-opensync 0.15-cvs20090410

- berry4all 0.3j



(all of these barry apps might not be necessary to making the Berry run as modem)



Other notes



*** The berry4all FAQs suggests updating /etc/resolv.conf with a nameserver  -- I

agree, with one twist:

If you will occasionally use the PC with wired high speed internet OR a different

internet access method other than the Berry, replace the name server in 

/etc/resolv.conf as follows:

#try opendns

nameserver 208.67.222.222



This name server is for OpenDNS.  Registration is free.  Using the wired 

high speed ISP's nameserver will make the Berry fail to resolve host names, 

BUT using the mobile provider's nameserver will makes the wired high speed

connection fail the same way.  Both will use OpenDNS with equal facility.



*** US Cellular has no way to automatically check data usage at present.  You have to call tech support and ask for a usage update.



*** The bump up to the premium (5GB) limit is $15 extra on top of $25 BIS data.



*** Don't expect any tech support help for Linux from US Cellular tech support.



*** US Cellular does not support any other phones as modems.



*** US Cellular's dial up process for berry-as-modem is a passthrough according

to Us Cellular tech support, meaning that they don't know nuthin' about nuthin'.

Therefore, the defaults listed for Windows' Desktop Manager at blackberry.com

might be a generally good resource for tweaking settings.



*** Tradition dictates that I post this while tethered with the Berry, so I did.



Regards,

pkcarlisle-at-gmail.com

author: PKC (Guest)
title: US Cellular 2 of 3
text:
# berry4all script and settings -- US Cellular
# by P.K. Carlisle 2009-11-03
# Tested and working on U.S. Cellular with a Blackberry 8330 Curve
'' 'BBT_OS'
'' 'AT&F'
OK 'ATZ'
OK 'ATI'
SAY 'Dialing...\n'
OK 'ATDT#777'
CONNECT
# Without ~p it does NOT continue past CONNECT
~p

author: PKC (Guest)
title: Us Cellular 1 of 3
text:
# berry4all script and settings -- US Cellular
# by P.K. Carlisle 2009-11-03
# Tested and working on U.S. Cellular with a Blackberry 8330 Curve
230400
noipdefault
defaultroute
#nomultilink
ipcp-restart 7
ipcp-accept-local
ipcp-accept-remote
lcp-echo-interval 0
lcp-echo-failure 999
nopcomp
noaccomp
pap-timeout 20
pap-restart 20
lcp-restart 10
nomagic
noccp
#noauth
crtscts
usepeerdns
novj
# does not exist in all pppd versions (osx)
#replacedefaultroute
#US Cellular will supply the user login nnnnnnnnnn
user nnnnnnnnnn@uscc.net
#US Cellular will supply the user password nnnnnnnnnn
password nnnnnnnnnn
#uncomment this command for test mode only
#dryrun
connect "/usr/sbin/chat -f /home/myhome/bbtether/conf/uscc-chat"

author: Guest (Guest)
title: Storm2
text: Attempting to connect with Storm2 on MacBookPro running snow leopard.  I am receiving "Failed to claim interface:"  I followed the instructions to remove pocketmac, I have BBdesktopmanager for mac on my comp, could this be causing this and is there a way around this?

author: Guest (Guest)
title: Connected But No Default Route
text: I connect to Verizon with no problems. The DNS servers show up in /etc/resolv.conf and there is an IP address for pppd. When I do a route -n there is no default route and I cannot get anywhere.

author: Guest (Guest)
title: My 2 cents.
text: we have a new macbook pro and just last night tried out the blackberry pro. with the hopes of tethering (was told that this was included  for free) well we now know it's not. can any one help us? thank you in advance...and we know basically nothing.

author: DavidBa (Guest)
title: Not quite working
text: Hi, I want to thank you for this useful utility!  I'm having a problem though.  I am able to connect, and browse the internet through Firefox.  However, when I try to connect using another application (Pidgin, XChat, etc.) I'm unable to connect.  Any idea how to correct this?  Using Ubuntu Jaunty and BB Tour 9630 on Verizon.  I have the tethering plan.

author: eode (Guest)
title: udevcontrol vs udevadm control
text:
for Ubuntu 9.04 (and presumably recent versions of debian) you have to use:

sudo udevadm control --reload-rules

instead of
sudo udevcontrol --reload-rules

author: Guest (Guest)
title: My 2 cents.
text: I'm getting the same problem as the last guy, but I recently upgraded by blackberry bold to the newest AT&T firmware 292, I used to use a modified version of 167.  I'm going to try the Rogers 282 and see if I get the same problems, would you have any tips on how to get it to work?  Is a setting for an ip address wrong?

author: Guest (Guest)
title: Bluetooth?
text: Do I need to have the USB cable connected or is there an option to tether via bluetooth?  It would be so cool to have Internet access on my a90 without even having to plug my 8820 into the netbook.

author: Admin (Guest)
title: To Matt
text:
Most linux do the charging automatically.
If not bbtether can do it for you. Make sure you use sudo to run it (usb access needs root). You might want to add "-c" option to force charging.
If it still can't access, then another module is preventing me to acces it (check with lsmod).

author: Matt (Guest)
title: Question about charging
text:
To be honest, I'm not using your app for tethering.  I was actually looking for an app to allow me to charge my Pearl via the USB port on my eeePC laptop.

Just wondering, is there a way to get more information on the message "Error increasing power error sending control message: Operation not permitted, continuing anyway" ?  Do I need to run the app as root?

author: Shannon VanWagner (Guest)
title: How to prevent Firefox from defaulting to "Offline Mode".
text:
To prevent having to uncheck "Use Offline" in Firefox every time, simply make these changes:
1.) Open Firefox, type in about:config in the address bar, then push Enter
2.) Click the "I'll be Careful I promise" button to go to the Firefox advanced configuration page.
3.) In the "Filter" area, type in toolkit.networkmanager.disable and it will show up as being set to the value of "false".
4.) Double-click the toolkit.networkmanager.disable setting in the main window to change its value to "true".
5.) Restart firefox and you should not have to disable "Use Offline" anymore.

Hope this makes your experience better!
Shannon VanWagner
humans enabled
